0.user_question: A certain company is in the business of selling fresh fruit. One crate of such fruit consists of 5 bananas, 12 apples, and 7 oranges. The price for such a crate depends on the price of its individual fruits. One apple costs $0.16666666666666666 and one banana costs twice as much. Oranges are the most expensive and cost three times as much as a banana per piece. What would be the price for such a crate of fruit?

1.subquestion: Let x represent the number representing an orange (in terms of ratio). Then what equation represents Banana Price(B) based upon Orange Price(O)?

subanswer.text: Since oranges are thrice as expensive as bananas, let B denote the price of a single banana; then O denotes the price of a single orange whereby \( \text{O} = 3\times\text{B}\), thus making our first variable dependent relation \(\text{O}=\text{x}\cdot\text{B}\) . Further continuing analysis shall involve additionitional stepwise manipulation toward establishment determination relating same object ['*"orange","cost"]to previously obtained result ...
